Graphical abstract Our graphic abstract shows the typical procedures of the resynthesis process, which involve six major steps: Pretreatment, leaching, purification, adjustment of Ni, Co, Mn concentrations, co-precipitation, and sintering. This review highlights the importance of recovering valuable metals from spent Li-ion battery (LIB) cathodes through the resynthesis of cathode active materials (CAMs). The resynthesis process of CAMs, a promising recycling method that directly produces CAM precursors from LIB leachate, is explored. This process encompasses six key steps, including pretreatment, leaching, purification, adjustment of metal concentrations, precursor synthesis, and sintering. The review also investigates the potential introduction of impurity elements during CAM resynthesis and provides tolerance levels for these impurities based on thorough reference analysis. Additionally, it addresses challenges related to the commercialization of the resynthesis process. Notably, this review represents the first comprehensive assessment of CAM resynthesis, including the systematic evaluation of 12 impurity elements (Fe, Li, Al, Cu, C, P, F, Na, Cl, S, Mg, and Zn). Overall, this comprehensive review is poised to support the commercial development of resynthesized CAMs by offering valuable guidelines for managing impurities and streamlining the purification process. Keywords Li-ion battery Recycling Resynthesis Leachate Impurity 1 Introduction Li-ion batteries (LIBs) have been widely used throughout various industrial applications such as electric vehicles (EVs), electronic devices, and energy storage systems due to their superior characteristics such as high energy density, long cycle life, and lightweight [1–4]. Specifically, the demand for LIBs is expected to skyrocket from 0.33 to 4 million metric tons from 2015 to 2040 due to the global trend of electrification in mobility [5]. As such, massive spent LIBs will be generated after their life spans of about 3 to 10 years [6]. The volume of waste LIBs will exceed 500 kilotons in 2044 and reach up to 1000 kilotons in 2050 [7]. Valuable metal resources inside spent LIB cathodes such as Li, Ni, and Co should be recovered by a proper recycling process to reuse them for the synthesis of cathode active materials (CAMs) to meet their surging demand. If these spent LIBs were not disposed properly, environmental risks would surely be incurred from toxic heavy metals and flammable organic electrolytes as well as potential risks to human health [8]. Meanwhile, the economic values of metal resources in spent LIBs are much higher than those from ores and CO2 emission is also lower than the mining of metal resources [9,10,11]. There are three representative methods for recycling spent LIBs including hydrometallurgy, pyrometallurgy, and direct recycling [12–15]. Hydrometallurgy involves a complicated physical treatment process of spent LIBs to obtain black mass, which contains valuable metals [16]. The black mass is then subject to acid leaching, followed by a solvent extraction process for metal recovery [17]. Li is also recovered through precipitation methods or electrochemical processes [18–20]. Fig. 1 summarizes the commercialized LIB recycling processes including the hydrometallurgy-based method [21–38]. Pyrometallurgy melts spent LIBs at high temperatures in a smelter, separating them into metal alloys and slag phases [39]. The obtained metal alloys are also subject to the hydrometallurgical process for the metal recovery. In contrast to hydrometallurgy and pyrometallurgy, direct recycling offers a relatively mild operation, where CAMs are separated from current collectors, binders, and conductive agents by various techniques including thermal treatment and chemical dissolution [40]. The separated CAMs with a Li deficient structure are regenerated by replenishing Li and subjecting them to a sintering process, as depicted in Fig. 2 [41–43]. Recently, an issue has arisen concerning the recycling of graphite [34], prompting ongoing research on its direct recycling [44–46]. Hydrometallurgy has such disadvantages as wastewater disposal, secondary pollutions, and expensive solvent extraction cost [12]. Pyrometallurgy has problems with greenhouse gas emissions and high energy consumption. By contrast, direct recycling requires a rigorous sorting/pre-processing and is difficult to guarantee the perfection of crystallinity for regenerated CAMs, which is attributed to the different degradation levels for each CAM particle [40]. The resynthesis of CAMs is a promising recycling approach that synthesizes precursors directly from LIB leachate. The resynthesis process differs from traditional hydrometallurgical and pyrometallurgical recycling processes because it eliminates the need for individual crystallization steps for each element, which typically necessitates complex separation processes. By bypassing these steps, the resynthesis can significantly reduce recycling costs and minimize wastewater generation. According to Zou et al. [47], the cost of resynthesizing LiNi1/3Mn1/3Co1/3O2 (NCM111) would be lower than a half of corresponding cost of synthesizing the same CAM from virgin materials. Their calculation was further elaborated and it was claimed that the profit margin could be about $5,000 per ton for the resynthesis of NCM111 [48]. The resynthesis approach can be basically applied to all kinds of CAMs, as exemplified by the first resynthesis of LiCoO2 (LCO) in 2002 [49]. However, the resynthesis approach is particularly effective for LiNi x Co y Mn z O2 (NCM), which has multiple transition metals (TMs) as constituent elements, unlike single TM CAMs including LCO, LiMn2O4 (LMO), and LiFePO4 (LFP). For instance, it was reported that resynthesized NCM111 demonstrated superior cycle performance compared to a commercial counterpart under the configuration of 1 Ah pouch-type full cells [50]. The concept of NCM resynthesis was first suggested separately by Wang group at Worcester Polytechnic Institute and Sohn group at Korea Institute of Geoscience and Mineral Resources in 2013 [47,51]. The difference between the direct recycling and the resynthesis of CAMs can be clearly illustrated by an analogy between the renovation of old buildings and the regeneration of degraded CAMs in Fig. 2. As the renovation of buildings can be classified into remodeling and reconstruction by whether their framework is maintained or not, the direct recycling and the resynthesis could be distinguished depending on whether the layered structure of degraded NCM is maintained or not during the LIB recycling. Therefore, all NCM compositions can be virtually realized via a coprecipitation method for precursor synthesis with the help of an adjustment step, during which the required amounts of TMs are added to the leachate for targeted NCM composition [52]. Also, the resynthesis process can be applied to black mass or alloy subject to the pyrometallurgical pretreatment of spent LIBs [52,53]. Despite these attractive merits of the resynthesis process, other impurities than Ni, Co, and Mn in the leachate could negatively affect the structural and electrochemical properties of resynthesized CAMs [40]. The effects of incorporated impurities in the NCM structure have been investigated by employing simulated leachate containing specific single impurity species or actual industrial leachate with multiple impurities [54–63]. There have been a few review papers partially covering the resynthesis process [64–66]. While Zhao et al. first summarized the regeneration methods of degraded CAMs including the resynthesis process [66], Jin et al. and Liu et al. used a term of indirect regeneration to describe the resynthesis process [64,65]. Fig. 3 displays the annual and cumulative number of research papers regarding the resynthesis process. Since the first related publication in 2013, the most popular term has been resynthesis, followed by regeneration. Given that the term of regeneration often implies both direct recycling and resynthesis, we opt for the term of resynthesis over regeneration and indirect regeneration. Herein, we have comprehensively analyzed relevant papers for the resynthesis process and organized their contents into four sections. Specifically, the typical resynthesis process including pretreatment, leaching, purification, and coprecipitation was described in the first section. Resynthesis attempts without purification were introduced in the second section, while the properties of resynthesized CAMs undergoing various purification steps were summarized in the third section. Lastly, the effects of impurity species were reviewed with the tolerance levels of impurities based on their respective electrochemical performance. This review paper would be the first exclusive review that covers the resynthesis process of CAMs with the systematic assessment of 12 kinds of impurity elements. Further, this review can facilitate the commercial development of resynthesized CAMs and help to streamline the purification process by supplying the guideline for impurities. 2 Typical procedures of resynthesis As seen in Fig. 4 , the resynthesis process of CAMs from spent LIBs involves six major steps. (i) Pretreatment to obtain black mass or alloy, (ii) leaching, (iii) purification for impurity removal, (iv) adjustment of Ni, Co, Mn concentrations, (v) synthesis of precursors using purified leachate, and (vi) sintering of precursors to CAMs [50]. 2.1 Pretreatment Among the three representative methods for recycling spent LIBs, pretreatment is particularly crucial for hydrometallurgy and direct recycling. The pretreatment can enhance the recovery efficiency of valuable elements in LIBs and reduce the energy consumption in the subsequent processes. The pretreatment is usually classified into discharge, dismantling, comminution, classification, separation, dissolution, and thermal treatment [67]. Because addressing the overall aspects of pretreatment would be out of scope, we briefly cover a procedure where degraded CAMs are isolated from spent LIBs, which corresponds to the separation, dissolution, and thermal treatment steps. First, it is beneficial to separate CAMs from Al current collectors before the leaching step to minimize the inflow of Al to the leachate. One of the most widely used separation methods is the dissolution of Al using alkali reagents. Sodium hydroxide is representatively used to dissolve Al as shown in Eq. (1) [68–75]. (1) 2Al(s) + 2NaOH(aq) + 2H2O(l) → 2NaAlO2(aq) + 3H2(g) Second, it is advantageous to dissolve organic binders such as polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF), resulting in the facile separation of CAMs from the Al foils. For instance, a highly polar organic solvent, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone, was used to dissolve the binders [76–78]. Lastly, residual organics from the binders and conductive agents on the surface of CAMs are often eliminated by thermal treatment [68,78]. 2.2 Leaching and purification The decomposition of black mass is industrially conducted by an acid leaching process using H2SO4 with reducing agents such as H2O2. Experimental parameters for the leaching process include the concentrations of acid and reducing agents, pulp density (ratio between solid and liquid, S/L), reaction time, temperature, etc. [68]. In particular, the S/L ratio is of importance for the resynthesis process because a condition of high S/L ratio with high leaching efficiency can generate concentrated leachate, which leads to the minimal usage of additional virgin metal resources during the following adjusting step. Also, the optimal S/L ratio promotes leaching rate by affecting ion transport and the probability of collision. Sometimes, LIB leachate needs to be under a N2 atmosphere to prevent Mn2+ from oxidation in air. Because CAMs have a variety of chemical composition and crystal structure, the separation and recovery of target elements are difficult, in particular, among various LIB constituent elements and impurities having similar chemical properties in black mass. Therefore, a combination of several purification methods is used to isolate each valuable element including Li, Co, and Ni in CAMs. A purification process is applied after the leaching step to remove impurities in LIB leachate. Various methods, such as chemical precipitation, solvent extraction, electrolysis, and ion exchange, have been attempted for the purification. Chemical precipitation is conducted by adding a reagent that reacts with target elements or impurity solutes to form insoluble precipitates from a liquid solution. Therefore, the purification of LIB leachate including Ni, Co, and Mn can be conducted by modulating the pH of leachate based on the contrasting precipitation behavior between main constituent elements for NCM and major impurity elements such as Fe [47]. Meanwhile, the addition of NaOH for the chemical precipitation results in a notable increase in the content of Na in the leachate, leading to a decrease in the concentrations of Ni, Co, and Mn [50]. The precipitates can then be separated from the leachate by filtration, centrifugation, or decantation. In addition to the simplicity and cost-effectiveness of chemical precipitation, the handling and transport of recovered solid precipitates is easy. However, the loss of strategic metals such as Ni, Co, and Mn becomes larger when the concentration of impurities is relatively high due to the detrimental effect of co-extraction. Besides, the chemical precipitation can produce a large amount of sodium sulfate, which needs to be carefully disposed of. Solvent extraction is a method where target elements or impurity solutes are extracted from a liquid solution into another liquid phase. They can be separated from the original leachate by adding a solvent that is immiscible with the original leachate and can dissolve them sufficiently, which is followed by the separation of two liquid phases. The solvent extraction conducted in the resynthesis process purifies the LIB leachate with the minimal loss of strategic metals after the chemical precipitation [52,79–84]. Dissolved metallic impurities in the leachate are transferred from aqueous to organic phases by solvent extractants, which extract targeted impurities by the formation of coordinated complexes. As industrial extractants, di(2-ethylhexyl) phosphoric acid (DEHPA) is widely used for selective extraction for Mn and bis(2,4,4-trimethylpentyl) phosphinic acid is a commercial extractant for the separation of Ni against Co [52,81,82,84]. The resulting coordinated metal complexes in the organic phase are stripped in strong acid, where stripped metal ions are separated, and used extractants can be recycled. While this method is highly efficient in the recovery of metals to a high degree of purity in the conventional LIB recycling, it is complex and costly, which requires specialized equipment and expertise. Further, this method generates a significant amount of waste including hazardous extractants, which should be properly treated. Electrolysis utilizes an electric current to facilitate non-spontaneous chemical reactions. In the context of LIB recycling, it often reclaims metals from LIB leachate by electrodeposition [83]. Ion exchange, on the other hand, purifies and separates ions in a solution by exchanging them with similarly charged ions on a resin [80]. Both methods vary in their efficiency for removing impurities and tend to have a relatively low environmental impact compared to alternative approaches. Nonetheless, electrolysis demands a significant amount of energy and ionic exchange has the drawbacks of costly equipment and maintenance, as well as the need for specialized resin materials. Among the purification methods, chemical precipitation and solvent extraction are more popular in the purification of LIB leachate. 2.3 Adjustment, coprecipitation, and sintering The adjustment supplements the purified leachate with additional TM salts to achieve the desired concentration and composition. While some studies omitted the adjustment step for the subsequent synthesis of precursors, most relevant studies have employed the adjustment step [71]. Although TM sulfates such as NiSO4, CoSO4, and MnSO4 are usually used for the adjustment [68], TM carbonates and acetates were also employed for the adjustment [70,76,77]. There are a couple of methods for the synthesis of precursors including coprecipitation and sol–gel methods. The coprecipitation method has been most widely used with advantages of the viability of homogeneous compositions in synthesized precursors and the suitability of mass production [75]. Typically, single phase precursor powder is formed during the coprecipitation using chelating agents such as NH4OH. The coprecipitation method is divided into hydroxide and carbonate coprecipitation. Precursors are precipitated in the form of Ni x Co y Mn z (OH)2 in the hydroxide coprecipitation [68], while precursors are formed as NixCo y Mn z CO3 in the carbonate coprecipitation [69]. The sol–gel method also uses chelating agents to promote hydrolytic and polymerization reactions, resulting in the gel formation with spatial structures [70,76]. Finally, precursors are converted into CAMs by sintering with Li sources such as Li2CO3 and LiOH. A sintering temperature typically ranges from 680 to 1000 °C, and a sintering atmosphere is either air or O2 for NCM. These sintering conditions including the type of Li sources, sintering temperature, and atmosphere depend on the Ni composition of NCM [52–63]. 3 Resynthesis without purification Unlike the resynthesis process associated with the typical purification methods mentioned above, there were some resynthesis attempts without the purification steps. NCM and LiNi x Co y Al z O2 (NCA) have been resynthesized without purification by the coprecipitation or sol–gel methods. Liu et al. varied the utilization rate of LCO leachate using maleic acid for the resynthesis of NCM811 by the hydroxide coprecipitation [53]. The interference of maleic acid in the chelating capability of ammonia worsened the electrochemical performance of resynthesized NCM811 due to the restricted growth of primary particles and a negative effect on the crystal structure. It was also found that the performance of NCM811 deteriorated as the utilization rate of LCO leachate increased. Similarly, Wang et al. varied the utilization rate of LCO leachate using sulfuric acid for the resynthesis of NCM955 by the hydroxide coprecipitation [85]. As the LCO leachate dosage increased, the surface of NCM particles became more irregular and the degree of cation mixing increased, which impaired the LIB performance of resynthesized NCM955. The electrochemically inactive nature of Al impurity was addressed in the consideration of discharge capacity. Muzayanha et al. compared HCl, H2SO4, and HNO3 as leaching agents for the resynthesis of NCA from unused NCA scraps by the hydroxide coprecipitation [72]. The morphology of resynthesized NCA particles was not uniform, which was attributed to the Al impurity, and their initial discharge capacity was lower than commercial NCA for all cases. The rate capability of resynthesized NCA was also inferior to the commercial one due to its irregular morphology. Beak et al. systematically compared the physicochemical and electrochemical properties of resynthesized NCM111 from industrial LIB leachate [54]. R-NCM, P-NCM, and SR-NCM were resynthesized via the coprecipitation from unpurified leachate, purified leachate, and simulated unpurified leachate where only metallic impurities were introduced without anionic impurities, respectively. R-NCM and SR-NCM showed an uneven particle size distribution compared to C-NCM, which was prepared from commercial TM salts, due to an excess amount of Al. The primary particle size of R-NCM was smaller than that of SR-NCM, indicating that anions hindered the particle growth. R-NCM showed the most severe initial capacity decay, while the initial capacity of P-NCM was substantially recovered compared to C-NCM. Whereas the rate capability of SR-NCM was inferior to that of R-NCM, the capacity retention of SR-NCM was higher than that of R-NCM. They proposed a concept of yield of precipitation, which was defined as the mole% ratio of a specific element in precursor to leachate, to investigate the precipitation behavior of impurities during the coprecipitation. Meanwhile, a sol–gel synthetic route after organic acid-based leaching was adopted for the resynthesis of NCM without purification steps. Yao et al. resynthesized NCM111 from black mass, which was leached by citric acid, by the sol-gel method [77]. The electrochemical properties of resulting NCM111 were slightly inferior to those of pristine NCM. Li et al. resynthesized NCM111 using the sol-gel method after leaching spent LIBs with lactic acid [73]. Resynthesized NCM111 demonstrated superior LIB performance compared to pristine NCM, which was attributed to the low cation mixing of resynthesized NCM. They further compared acetic and maleic acids as both leaching and chelating agents in the resynthesis of NCM111 by the sol-gel method [70]. The case of maleic acid showed better LIB performance than acetic acid, which was ascribed to their different chelating capability. 4 Resynthesis with specific purification methods The most widely adopted purification method for the resynthesis of CAMs is pH-modulated precipitation [47,48,50,53,86–89]. They paid attention to the precipitation behavior of Fe, which is precipitated at a lower pH than Ni, Co, and Mn [47]. Therefore, most major metallic impurities including Fe can be more or less removed before the onset pH for the coprecipitation of NCM precursors. In some cases, a combined process of chemical precipitation, solvent extraction, ionic exchange, and electrolysis was applied to the purification of LIB leachate [52,79–84]. A purification process for impurities was conducted through precipitation by pH control in the leachate of mixed CAMs of LCO, LMO, NCM111, and LFP [86,88]. After the purification step via pH control, impurities such as Fe, Al, and Cu were successfully removed below a concentration of 50 ppm. NCM111, NCM523, and NCM622 that were prepared after the purification exhibited well-ordered layered structures (R-3 m space group) without any impurity phases [48,86,88]. The resynthesized CAMs also showed comparable electrochemical performance to their counterparts from virgin materials. Meanwhile, it was confirmed that Li ions in the leachate were not coprecipitated into resynthesized hydroxide precursors due to a high solubility of Li salts in water [86,88]. The Li ions in the leachate could be recovered as Li2CO3 in the last stage during the resynthesis process by adding Na2CO3 [51,83,84]. Zheng et al. resynthesized NCM111 from four types of spent EV batteries, whose CAMs were NCM + LMO, NCM + LMO + LFP, NCM + NCA + LMO, and NCM + NCA + LMO + LCO + LFP from Ford, GM, Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, and A123 Systems, respectively [53]. Spent batteries in each group underwent a series of pretreatment steps and subsequent H2SO4 leaching with H2O2. After the pH-modulated impurity removal and the adjustment step, the targeted NCM111 composition was realized via the coprecipitation and a two-step sintering process. Resynthesized NCM111 from each group showed a comparable LIB performance to a pristine NCM111 sample with improved rate properties, which was attributed to its relatively large pore volume. Ma et al. focused on the porosity issue in resynthesized NCM111 samples from purified leachate where high recovery rates (>90%) of Ni, Co, and Mn were confirmed [50]. It was demonstrated that internal pores within secondary particles reduced tensile stress on the particles via a 3D modeling analysis, consequently improving the cycle performance of the resynthesized CAMs compared to a control sample. They further detected a thicker cathode electrolyte interphase layer on the surface of resynthesized NCM111 after 4000 cycles, which was the evidence of superior mechanical property to the counterpart. Chen et al. resynthesized NCM111 after the removal of impurities by pH-modulated precipitation on a large scale of 30 kg of spent LIBs [89]. Coprecipitation parameters such as pH and flow rate were optimized to achieve the desired particle size distribution and tap density of the resynthesized CAMs. Their excellent rate performance compared to a control sample was similarly attributed to internal pores in the center of secondary particles enabling high electrolyte uptake, which leads to faster Li-ion diffusion during cycling. The pH-modulated chemical precipitation by the addition of NaOH has also been adopted elsewhere [54,90,91]. Kim et al. investigated the precipitation behavior of Ni, Co, Mn, and impurities in LIB leachate upon the addition of NaOH under various pH conditions [91]. At pH 4.5 in the leachate, the majority of Zn, a significant amount of Al, and some Fe and Cu were precipitated. At pH 5.5 and 6.5, the majority of Al and Cu as well as a fair amount of Fe were further precipitated and removed. However, with the increase in pH from 5.5 to 6.5, the loss rates of Ni, Co, and Mn increased significantly from 20%, 10%, 10% to 40%, 20%, 10%, respectively. Resynthesized NCM622 under the condition of pH 5.5 showed similar morphology characteristics and initial capacity to bare NCM622 with improved cyclability. Beak et al. resynthesized CAMs (P-NCM) using purified LIB leachate by the pH control using NaOH [54]. An X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis showed extra impurity peaks (S 2p at 169 eV) of P-NCM, which originated from the bonding energy of SO4 2−. The LIB performance of P-NCM including initial discharge capacity, rate capability, and cyclability was slightly hindered compared to a bare NCM sample. Do et al. purified LIB leachate, which resulted from bioleaching using A. ferrooxidans, by the pH-modulated precipitation with NaOH [90]. The A. ferrooxidans-mediated bioleaching achieved leaching efficiencies of 85.50% for Ni, 91.83% for Mn, 90.37% for Co, and 89.89% for Li via a multi-step leaching process. An additional air purging process was conducted for the sake of the oxidation of Fe2+ ions to lower the precipitation pH of Fe species from pH 7. Therefore, Al3+, Cu2+, and Fe species could be removed efficiently under pH 4.5 with minimizing the precipitation loss of Ni, Co, and Mn. NCM111 and NCM622 were resynthesized using the purified leachate via an oxalic coprecipitation method and their rate and cycle performance was on par with commercial samples. Metal impurities can be precipitated as phosphates or carbonates other than hydroxides as Wang et al. and Krüger et al. aimed for the purification of LIB leachate [92,93]. Wang et al. added H3PO4 to LIB leachate, which was obtained by DL-malic acid leaching with glucose, to precipitate Fe3+ ions in the form of FePO4 at pH 3.6 [93]. They needed an additional oxidizing step for the formation of Fe3+ ions from Fe2+ ions using H2O2 as an oxidant. While the Fe content in the leachate was reduced from 0.15% to less than 0.05%, the total loss rate of Ni, Co, and Mn during the purification process was around 10%. NCM111 was resynthesized using the purified leachate via the oxalic coprecipitation method and an improvement in initial discharge capacity and cycle performance was observed compared to a commercial sample. Metal impurities including Al, which originated from electrode production rejects and spent LIBs, were precipitated as carbonates [92]. The impurity concentration was higher in the purified leachate of spent LIBs than that of rejects. The Al impurity hindered the formation of secondary precursor particles particularly in the purified leachate of spent LIBs. An Al-related crystalline peak was detected only in a resynthesized sample from the spent LIBs by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. Other purification methods than chemical precipitation have usually been employed by their combinations such as a combination of chemical precipitation and solvent extraction [48,79,81,82,84]. Yang et al. applied a combined purification method of NaOH-employed precipitation and solvent extraction using DEHPA [81]. Subsequently, Li-rich NCM was resynthesized from the purified leachate, in which the concentrations of impurities (Al, Cu, and Fe) were reduced below 0.5 wt%. Yang et al. controlled the pH of leachate to remove Al, Fe, and Cu impurities, followed by a solvent extraction method using DEHPA with sulfonated kerosene solvent [84]. The purified leachate was then used to resynthesize NCM111, where all impurities remained at levels below 0.006 wt%. Zhao et al. prepared leachate from metal alloys obtained through pyrometallurgical treatment, and resynthesized LiNi0.92Co0.05Mn0.03O2 [52]. They performed a three-step purification process of the first solvent extraction using LIX 984 extractant for eliminating Cu2+, the second pH-modulated precipitation for the removal of Fe species, and the final solvent extraction using DEHPA for remaining impurities. The resulting concentrations of impurities in the purified leachate were reduced below 5 ppm. Regarding the properties of the resynthesized CAMs in the three above-mentioned papers [52,81,84], similar morphological, structural, and electrochemical characteristics to pristine NCM samples were reported. By contrast, there are a couple of studies showing slightly inferior electrochemical properties of resynthesized CAMs via the combined purification of chemical precipitation and solvent extraction [79,82]. Zheng et al. first removed Fe through pH-controlled precipitation and then conducted two-step solvent extraction with different kinds of extractants for the separation of other impurities [79]. The impurity concentrations of resynthesized NCM111 eventually became less than 0.03 wt%. Weng et al. eliminated Cu and Mg impurities in the leachate of spent LIBs using Na2S and NaF, respectively [82]. Fe and Al impurities could be removed by the pH-modulated precipitation, while the solvent extraction method using DEHPA was also implemented. The concentrations of Cu, Mg, Fe, and Al in the purified leachate dropped to 8, 6, 2, and 2 ppm, respectively. As aforementioned, resynthesized NCM111 by Zheng et al. and Weng et al. exhibited relatively degraded electrochemical properties including initial discharge capacity, rate, and cycle performance [79,82]. On the other hand, an additional purification method such as electrolysis was adopted in addition to chemical precipitation and solvent extraction by Peng et al. [83]. Fe3+ and Al3+ ions in LIB leachate were initially removed by increasing pH to 3.5 and 5.25, respectively. In particular, an ammonia solution for increasing the pH of leachate from 3.5 to 5.25 was found to minimize the loss of Ni, Co, and Mn. The subsequent methods of electrolysis and solvent extraction using N902 were implemented to remove Cu2+ impurity. The resulting concentrations of Fe, Al, and Cu in the purified leachate fell to the levels of 1.1, 2.3, and 3.4 ppm, respectively, followed by the resynthesis of NCM424. The structural and morphological characteristics of resynthesized NCM424 as well as its LIB performance were similar to bare samples. Even though it is rare to exclude the chemical precipitation for the purification of LIB leachate, there was a case where ion exchange and solvent extraction methods were combined [80]. NCM811, NCM523, and NCM111 were resynthesized in the purified leachate without the comparison of their LIB performance with a pristine sample. A comprehensive summary of the references covered in this section is described in Table S1. 5 Effects of impurities on the properties of resynthesized CAMs 5.1 Effects of single impurity element As seen in Fig. 5 , various impurity elements can be incorporated during the resynthesis of CAMs. Fe, Li, Al, Cu, C, Si, P, and F are constituent elements for various battery components including casing, active materials, current collectors, binders, and electrolyte. While Na, Cl, and S could be introduced during the and leaching steps, Mg, Ca, and Zn are minor and omnipresent impurity elements that could originate from equipment for dismantling and comminution. 5.1.1 Fe Fe is an omnipresent impurity element that can be readily incorporated from LFP, battery casings, and machinery parts during the LIB recycling process. Zhang et al. investigated the properties of Fe2+ or Fe3+-incorporated NCM622 by adopting different Fe sources in simulated LIB leachate [94]. The negative effect of Fe3+ ions was observed on the particle morphology and crystal structure of Fe3+-incorporated NCM622 in Fig. 6 (a) and Fig. 7 (a1). Whereas the overall LIB performance of Fe3+-incorporated NCM622 deteriorated regardless of the Fe doping level from 0.2 to 5 mol%, the initial discharge capacity and rate capability were improved when appropriate amounts (0.2 and 1 mol%) of Fe2+ ions were introduced to NCM622 as shown in Fig. 7(a2 and a3). Park et al. scrutinized the tolerance level of Fe impurity for NCM111 and investigated the effect of trace Fe on the structural stability and electrochemical performance of NCM811 [56,95]. The introduction of small amounts (0.05 or 0.25 mol%) of Fe improved the LIB performance of NCM111, whereas 1% of Fe aggravated the overall LIB performance. In particular, the positive effects of Fe on the cyclability of NCM111 was demonstrated, which was attributed to the mitigated dissolution of TMs during cycling. Meanwhile, NCM811 with a trace amount (0.25 mol%) of Fe showed enhanced LIB performance compared to pristine NCM due to the superior structural integrity of Fe-incorporated NCM811. 5.1.2 Li Even though Li is a constituent element of NCM, Li could be considered as an impurity during the coprecipitation for the precursors of NCM. Jo et al. synthesized NCM111 precursors in simulated LIB leachate containing Li sulfate as well as Ni, Co, and Mn sulfates by the coprecipitation [62]. The presence of residual Li during the coprecipitation did not affect the morphology and particle size of synthesized hydroxide precursors as shown in Fig. 6(b). The initial capacity and rate capability of synthesized NCM111 were aggravated when residual Li was contained in the precursors owing to a decrease in the crystallinity as shown in Fig. 7(b). 5.1.3 Al Al is usually a major impurity in LIB leachate because the separation of CAMs from Al current collectors cannot be completed before the leaching step. Once Al flows into CAMs, it has a tendency to substitute Ni or Co sites [96–100]. With an Al impurity content of 5 mol%, resynthesized NCM111 and NCM622 had LiAlO2 and LiMnO3 impurity phases, respectively, as shown in Fig. 7(c1) [97,100]. Fig. 6(c) shows that the involvement of Al impurity in the formation of precursor particles resulted in their irregular size distribution [98,55]. A decrease in initial capacity is the common issue of Al impurity in CAMs [55,96,99]. Kim et al. synthesized NCM111 with a trace amount of Al impurity to investigate its effect on the LIB performance of NCM111. Fig. 7(c2 and c3) show that the electrochemical properties of Al-incorporated NCM111 (up to 2 mol%) including initial capacity, Coulombic efficiency, and capacity retention deteriorated except for rate performance compared to a bare sample. The presence of small amounts of Al in the NCM structure facilitated Li-ion transfer, leading to the reduced impedance of Al-incorporated NCM [55,97,100]. Furthermore, its thermal stability was enhanced with a higher onset temperature compared to a bare sample, which was attributed to the stronger Al–O bond than that of Ni/Co/MnO bond [54]. On the contrary, Kaddami et al. and Zhang et al. reported the improved initial capacity of Al-incorporated NCM111 and NCM622 as well as enhanced rate capability and cycle performance with a trace amount of Al [98,100]. 5.1.4 Cu Cu impurity can be introduced from the anode current collectors of spent LIBs. In general, the incorporation of Cu tends to affect the morphology of resynthesized CAMs. Specifically, the sizes of primary and secondary particles become smaller with irregular shapes and an uneven distribution compared to a bare sample as shown in Fig. 6(d). Due to the stable formation of complex ions between Cu2+ ions and ammonia during the coprecipitation, the resulting composition of Cu in the NCM structure is prone to having a low value compared to a designed composition. Although the exact substitution site of Cu in the NCM structure is still uncertain, several studies have provided relevant information. For example, Zhang et al. confirmed that Cu2+ ions occupy Ni sites in NCM622 by comparing the concentrations of TMs [101]. On the other hand, Sa et al. found that Cu2+ ions occupy Mn sites in NCM111 as an electrochemical reaction around 4.6 V related to Mn species was gradually inhibited with increasing Cu content [102]. Additionally, Wu et al. reported that the substitution sites vary depending on the amount of Cu in NCM811 [103]. They argued that Cu occupies Ni sites when the Cu content is 2 mol%, while occupying Mn sites for 0.5 and 1 mol%. The crystallinity of precursors tends to be degraded as Cu ions are introduced, while no structural deformation of CAMs is observed at the impurity level of Cu. On the other hand, Zhang et al. observed a secondary phase corresponding to Li2MnO3 in 5 mol% of Cu-incorporated NCM622 as seen in Fig. 7(d1) [101]. The relatively large ionic radius of Cu2+ and the low binding energy of Cu–O bond compared to other TMs increase lattice parameters. Lu et al. attributed the increased lattice parameters of Cu-incorporated NCM to the strong repulsive force between oxygen layers [104]. Meanwhile, the impact of Cu on the LIB performance of resynthesized NCM has varied depending on the NCM composition. Jo et al. and Sa et al. confirmed that the discharge capacity and rate capability deteriorated in Cu-incorporated NCM111 as shown in Fig. 7(d3) [63,102]. They attributed the performance degradation to the decrease in the amount of electrochemical active Ni2+ ions. By contrast, superior electrochemical properties were reported for Ni-rich NCM compositions such as NCM622 and 811 below 5 mol% Cu, which was ascribed to the increased c-lattice parameter and decreased cation mixing, as shown in Fig. 7(d2) [101,103,104]. 5.1.5 C Although carbon is not usually considered as a dopant in CAMs, the effect of carbon as an impurity in the LIB recycling needs to be addressed because carbon from conductive agents and anode active materials could exist in LIB leachate [105]. Even though carbon cannot be dissolved by regular acid leaching, it is practically impossible to remove residual carbon entirely by filter papers with micrometer pore sizes. Thus, understanding the effects of carbon on the quality of recovered precursors and CAMs is crucial. In the case of conductive agents, Zheng et al. examined the inner structure of precursors containing Super C65 carbon black and observed holes in the center of some precursor particles in Fig. 6(e) [106]. The center of cross-sectioned precursor particles showed a strong carbon signal, which was consistent with the location of holes with many carbon nanoparticles. However, the carbon nanoparticles were removed during a high temperature sintering process at 850 °C for 18 h, leading to the formation of void in C-introduced NCM622. The overall LIB performance of C-introduced NCM622 is inferior to pristine NCM due to severe cation mixing and lattice distortion, as exemplified by the comparison of initial charge/discharge capacity, rate capability, and cyclability in Fig. 7(e). Therefore, it was suggested that residual carbon should be eliminated before the leaching step. 5.1.6 F Because F is a constituent element for LiPF6 salt in electrolyte and PVDF binder, F is expected to be incorporated into LIB leachate. Zhang et al. synthesized NCM622 in simulated LIB leachate by varying the amount of NaF as a F source [107]. Whereas the surface morphology of F-containing precursors was identical to a bare sample, their internal morphology was significantly altered with the formation of holes as the F content increased from 0.2 to 5.0 mol% as shown in Fig. 6(f). The occupancy of oxygen sites by F on the surface of secondary particles of F-containing NCM (FNCM) increased the ratios of Ni2+/Ni3+ and Co2+/Co3+ due to charge compensation. The overall LIB performance of 0.2 and 1 mol% FNCM was enhanced compared to pristine NCM (VNCM), which was ascribed to internal holes, expanded lattice volume, and the increased ratios of Ni2+/Ni3+ and Co2+/Co3+, as shown Fig. 8 (a). By contrast, 5 mol% FNCM showed aggravated LIB performance due to severe cation mixing and structural instability from an excessive increment in the Co2+/Co3+ ratio. 5.1.7 P P could be incorporated into LIB leachate, because LiPF6 salts and LFP contain P. Zheng et al. utilized simulated LIB leachate to synthesize NCM622 by varying the amount of Na3PO4 as a P source [108]. During the coprecipitation, PO4 3− ions negatively affected the nucleation and precipitation of precursors, leading to the formation of irregular particle morphology of P-containing NCM (PNCM) as shown in Fig. 6(g). Excessive PO4 3− ions formed a secondary phase of Li3PO4, particularly in 5PNCM where 5 mol% P was introduced during the coprecipitation as shown in Fig. 8(b1), causing a Li deficiency in the PNCM structure. The overall LIB performance of PNCM was inferior to pristine NCM (VNCM) as shown in Fig. 8(b2 and b3), which was attributed to irregular particle morphology, and deficient Li by the impurity phase. Therefore, it was suggested to eliminate the PO4 3− ions for the resynthesis of NCM. 5.1.8 Na Na can be easily introduced in the resynthesis process when spent LIBs are discharged with a saline solution. Therefore, Na is a major impurity element, which needs to be handled carefully for the resynthesis of CAMs. Beak et al. added 12.6 mol% of Na2SO4 based on the actual Na content in industrial leachate to a TM solution to investigate the effect of Na on NCM811 [57]. As the number of precursor washing increased, Na content in NCM811 showed a decreasing tendency from 2.46 (CAM whose precursor was not washed (W0)) to 0.14 (CAM whose precursor was washed 1 time (W1)) and 0.02 mol% (CAM whose precursor was washed 6 times (W6)). Although there was no noticeable change in the particle morphology of Na-incorporated CAM as seen in Fig. 6(h), impurity peaks related to Na2SO4 were observed in the W0 sample. Fig. 8(c) shows that the electrochemical properties of the W6 sample outperformed a bare NCM sample in terms of initial capacity, rate capability, and cycling performance. The improved LIB performance of the W6 sample was attributed to a higher Li-ion diffusion coefficient and a lower internal resistance, while the W0 and W1 samples showed inferior electrochemical performance to the bare sample. 5.1.9 Cl Cl is also likely to be introduced along with Na during the discharging step using a saline solution. The effect of Cl on resynthesized CAMs was reported only for CAMs prepared via the sol–gel method [109,110], while there are no relevant studies on CAMs that are prepared by the coprecipitation method. Cl-incorporated CAMs (from 5 to 15 mol% for NCM111 and from 3 to 10 mol% for NCM424) did not contain secondary phases, leading to the enlargement of a and c lattice parameters due to the larger ionic radius of Cl− (1.81 Å) than that of O2− (1.40 Å) and the corresponding increase in TM ionic radius due to charge compensation. It was claimed that the introduction of Cl into both NCM111 and NCM424 enhances the overall LIB performance due to an expanded pathway for Li-ion (de)intercalation and reduced electrostatic repulsion between OMO interlayers, as seen in Fig. 8(d) [109]. However, with an excessive amount (>5 mol%) of Cl, NCM111 displayed a noticeable increase in overpotential. 5.1.10 S Because sulfuric acid is a common leaching agent to dissolve TMs, S easily exists in LIB leachate. Lee et al. investigated the properties of S-incorporated NCM111 (NCMS) using simulated LIB leachate containing excessive sulfate ions [59]. The S-incorporated precursors possessed a relatively porous surface compared to pristine precursors, suggesting that excessive S impurity hinders the growth of secondary particles. Relatively larger primary particles were observed in NCMS than pristine NCM111 (NCM) as shown in Fig. 6(i). A secondary phase corresponding to Li2SO4 in the XRD pattern of NCMS in Fig. 8(e1) indicates that S impurity could remain in the NCM structure. Fig. 8(e2) displays that the LIB performance of NCMS was similar or slightly decreased compared to pristine NCM. 5.1.11 Mg Mg is one of the ubiquitous impurity elements in the LIB recycling process. The incorporation of Mg in CAMs generally leads to the reduction of secondary particle size compared to a bare sample as seen in Fig. 6(j) [82,97,111]. Although Mg ions can initially exist in the TM layers of NCM structure, a portion of Mg ions relocates to Li layers during cycling due to a similar ionic radius between Li+ (0.76 Å) and Mg2+ (0.72 Å) [82,112,113]. The immobilized Mg2+ ions in the Li layers could function as pillars, preventing local structural collapse. For example, the trace amount (1 mol%) of Mg in NCM111 resulted in an enhanced cycle retention property [82]. By contrast, the initial discharge capacity of Mg-incorporated NCM becomes inevitably lower due to the electrochemically inactive characteristic of Mg2+ [82,111,112,113]. Fig. 9 (a1 and a2) clearly show such a trend in the initial discharge capacity and capacity retention of Mg-incorporated NCM622 [112,113]. Huang et al. also pointed out that the high bond dissociation energy of Mg–O (394 kJ mol−1) in comparison to NiO (391 kJ mol−1) could contribute to the improved cycle performance [113]. Incidentally, the enhanced thermal stability of Mg-incorporated NCM622 was observed as seen in Fig. 9(a3) [111,112]. 5.1.12 Zn Zn, which is one of omnipresent impurities, can be easily incorporated in LIB leachate during the LIB recycling process. Zn2+ ions in the LIB leachate can be easily coprecipitated into precursors with Ni, Co, and Mn. There are a couple of research papers where Zn was considered as an impurity or doping element during the coprecipitation step. Lu et al. evaluated the electrochemical properties of 1 mol% Zn-incorporated NCM622 [114], and Jeong et al. investigated the impact of Zn impurity whose content varied to 0.5% in NCM955 (NCMZ955) [58]. As the Zn content increased, the secondary particle size of NCMZ955 decreased, which was attributed to the relatively low solubility product constant of Zn(OH)2 compared to those of Ni, Co, and Mn, as shown in Fig. 6(k). The XRD patterns in Fig. 9(b1) indicate that small amounts (<0.5 mol%) of Zn in NCMZ955 do not affect the NCM crystal structure with no secondary phases. However, a distinct Li10Zn4O9 impurity phase was found when an excessive amount (5 mol%) of Zn replace Co in NCM (NMZ955). It was suggested that Zn, which could be incorporated into both TM and Li sites, expands the c-axis and acts as a pillar. As a result, 0.5 mol% Zn-incorporated NCMZ955 showed better cyclability at a high voltage range and rate capability compared to NCM955. On the other hand, the incorporation of Zn in both NCM955 and NCM622 caused a decrease in initial charge/discharge capacity due to the electrochemically inactive nature of Zn species. Fig. 9(b2–b4) compare the overall LIB performance between Zn-incorporated NCM955, NCMZ955 and NMZ955. 5.2 Effects of multiple impurity elements The effects of multiple elements in the form of a single species or the combination of impurity elements during the resynthesis process have been addressed by some researchers. Park et al. compared the impacts of various PF6 - sources including LiPF6, NH4PF6, and LIB electrolyte (LiPF6 in ethylene carbonate/ethyl methyl carbonate) on NCM811 that was synthesized by the coprecipitation [61]. LiPF6 and NH4PF6 exerted positive effects on the structural stability and LIB performance of NCM. In particular, passivated layers on NCM prevented TM dissolution during cycling in the case of NH4PF6, resulting in enhanced cyclability compared to pristine NCM. The introduction of the organic solvents worsened the LIB performance of NCM due to the smaller secondary particles of precursors and the relatively rough surface of CAMs compared to pristine NCM. Lee et al. synthesized NCM955 using simulated LIB leachate containing NaCl, which can be incorporated during the saline discharge process, by the coprecipitation [60]. NaCl-incorporated precursors were washed with deionized water for 0, 1, and 6 times to vary the amount of NaCl in the precursors. The particle size of resulting CAMs decreased, while the c-axis parameter increased compared to pristine NCM samples. The increase in the c-axis could be attributed to the substitution of Na and Cl ions for Li and O, respectively. NaCl-incorporated CAMs with no washing contained a secondary phase related to LiNaSO4. NaCl-incorporated CAMs after 6 time washing showed better electrochemical properties than the pristine due to expanded Li layer thickness, relatively low cation mixing, and structural stability. On the other hand, NaCl-incorporated CAMs with 0 and 1 time washing exhibited inferior initial discharge capacity and rate capability than the pristine owing to the presence of impurity phase and excessive impurities. Jeong et al. adopted simulated LIB leachate with trace amounts of Fe (0.25 mol%) and Al (0.05 mol%) to investigate the effects of Fe and Al on the structural and electrochemical properties of resynthesized NCM111 [115]. Fe and Al-incorporated NCM111 exhibited an expanded c-lattice parameter, which enhanced rate capability with reduced overpotential at high C-rates, whereas its discharge capacity and cyclability were worsened compared to pristine NCM. 5.3 Tolerance levels of impurities Fig. 10 provides the tolerance levels of impurity elements in NCM. The tolerance levels were determined from the maximum concentration of impurity in LIB leachate, with which at least two LIB properties of resynthesized NCM among initial capacity, rate capability, and cyclability are not worse than pristine NCM. It is worthy of note that the tolerance levels vary in references for a specific impurity element. For example, the references on Mg-incorporated NCM622 reported the tolerance Mg levels from no tolerance to ∼1500 ppm in leachate. Meanwhile, well-known dopants to NCM such as Al have a tendency that rate capability and cyclability are enhanced sacrificing the initial capacity of NCM, which could be tolerated from the commercial perspective. Incidentally, the mol% of Na in NCM was regulated by the number of washing [57], which necessitated the distinction between the Na concentration in as-synthesized NCM and leachate in Fig. 10. 6 Summary Valuable metal resources inside spent LIB cathodes such as Li, Ni, and Co should be recovered by a proper recycling process to reuse them for the synthesis of CAMs to meet their surging demand. The resynthesis process of CAMs is a promising recycling approach that synthesizes precursors directly from LIB leachate. The resynthesis process of CAMs from spent LIBs involves six major steps. (i) Pretreatment to obtain black mass or alloy, (ii) leaching, (iii) purification for impurity removal, (iv) adjustment of Ni, Co, Mn concentrations, (v) synthesis of precursors using purified leachate, and (vi) sintering of precursors to CAMs. The pretreatment can enhance the recovery efficiency of the valuable elements in the LIBs and reduce the energy consumption in the subsequent processes. The decomposition of black mass is industrially conducted by an acid leaching process using H2SO4 with reducing agents such as H2O2. Various purification methods, such as chemical precipitation, solvent extraction, electrolysis, and ion exchange, have been attempted. However, the most widely adopted purification method for the resynthesis of CAMs is pH-modulated precipitation. Most relevant studies have employed the adjustment step before the subsequent resynthesis of cathode precursors. The coprecipitation method has been most widely used with advantages of the viability of homogeneous compositions in synthesized precursors and the suitability of mass production. Finally, precursors are converted into CAMs by sintering with Li sources such as Li2CO3 and LiOH. Unlike the resynthesis process associated with the typical purification methods mentioned above, there were some resynthesis attempts without the purification steps. Meanwhile, various impurity elements can be incorporated during the resynthesis of CAMs. In addition to Fe, Li, Al, Cu, C, P, and F, which are constituent elements for LIBs, Na, Cl, S, Mg, and Zn could be introduced during the overall LIB recycling process. Table 1 summarizes the references on the effects of single impurity elements. We also attempt to provide the tolerance level of the impurity elements by analyzing relevant references to facilitate the purification process. 7 Perspective and challenges Last but not least, the issues for the commercialization of the resynthesis process should be addressed as follows. First, there is a lack of studies on the resynthesis of Ni-rich NCM from industrial LIB leachate. A few research papers have reported the resynthesis of NCM811 and NCM955 [56–58], which are usually considered for the EV application. However, all these papers adopted simulated LIB leachate to investigate the effects of specific impurity elements on resynthesized NCM. Second, a more systematic evaluation of impurity tolerance level is necessary. As clearly evidenced by Fig. 10, the tolerance level varies significantly from references to references for a specific impurity element. What is worse, there are not enough studies to draw a unanimous conclusion on the tolerance level of impurity elements. The final emerging issue would be the low utilization rate of LIB leachate for the resynthesis of Ni-rich NCM. As we have monitored the composition of industrial LIB leachate from SungEel HiTech, which is the largest LIB recycling company that collects various LIB products in Korea, the Ni:Co:Mn ratio in their LIB leachate is 5.5:2.8:1.7 in 2022. This ratio would be ideal for the resynthesis of NCM622 with minimizing the usage of additional virgin TM salts, in particular, NiSO4. If we try to resynthesize Ni-rich NCM811 and NCM955 from industrial LIB leachate with the current Ni:Co:Mn ratio, the utilization rate of LIB leachate would be much lower. However, it is evident that the Ni:Co:Mn ratio in industrial LIB leachate is shifting to Ni-rich compositions as monitored from 4.2:3.6:2.2 in 2020 to 5.5:2.8:1.7 in 2022. Therefore, it is anticipated that the utilization rate of LIB leachate will be accelerated accordingly. Dongwoo Kim is currently pursuing a master's degree in energy & mineral resources engineering at Sejong University located in Seoul, Korea. He earned his bachelor's degree in the Department of Energy & Mineral Resources Engineering from Sejong University in 2022. His research interests encompass the development of Li-ion battery (LIB) cathode materials and hydrometallurgical battery recycling. Hyeoncheol Joo is currently pursuing a master's degree in energy & mineral resources engineering at Sejong University located in Seoul, Korea. He earned his bachelor's degree in the Department of Energy & Mineral Resources Engineering from Sejong University in 2023. His research interests encompass the resynthesis of LIB cathode materials and battery recycling. Chanmin Kim is studying for a master’s degree under the guidance of Prof. Kyungjung Kwon in the Department of Energy Resources Engineering at Sejong University. He is currently investigating the effect of the purity of recycled Mn reagents on LiNiCoMnO2 (NCM) cathode materials and the direct recycling of spent NCM, LiNiCoAlO2 (NCA) cathode materials. Seoa Kim is a master student in the Department of Energy & Mineral Resources Engineering at Sejong University under the supervision of Prof. Kyungjung Kwon. Current research focuses on the direct recycling of spent NCM cathode materials and the regeneration of NCA cathode materials. Wan-Yi Kim received his Ph.D. from the Universite de Montreal in 2011 and worked as a post-doctoral fellowship in McGill University by 2013. He joined POSCO Technical Research Lab. as a senior researcher in 2013 for steelmaking process. He has joined recently POSCO Holdings LiB Materials R&D Laboratories in 2021. His research interests currently focus on the extraction of valuable materials such as Li, Ni, and Co from spent end-of-life LIBs. His recent ongoing research includes the development of the eco-friendly LIB recycling process using a new concept of pyro-hydro coupled process. Sangwoo Han received his Ph.D. from the Pohang University of Science and Technology in 2021. He joined POSCO Technical Research Lab. as a researcher in 2009 for steelmaking process. He has joined recently POSCO Holdings LiB Materials R&D Laboratories in 2021. His research interests currently focus on the process design for electric vehicle LIB recycling. His recent ongoing research includes the development of the eco-friendly LIB recycling process through pyro-met. Joongkil Park is a research fellow and center leader of LiB Recycling Research Center at the LiB Material R&D Laboratories of POSCO Holdings. He received a Ph.D. degree in the Department of Metals & Materials Engineering at the University of British Columbia in Canada in 2002. Soyeon Park is a master student in the Department of Future Energy Convergence at Seoul National University of Science & Technology under the supervision of Prof. Heechul Jung. Her current research focuses on surface treatment of cathode materials and designing of thick LiFePO4 electrodes for high rate-capability. Heechul Jung received his Ph.D. degree in the Department of Materials Science & Engineering at Seoul National University in 2011. He worked for Samsung Advanced Institute of Technology and Samsung SDI from 2011 to 2021 and joined Dong-A University from 2021 to 2024. Currently, he is a faculty member in the Department of Future Convergence at Seoul National University of Science & Technology. His research interests are mainly focused on alloy-type anode materials, surface treatment of cathode materials, and design of electrode for high-energy density LIBs. Sanghyuk Park received a Ph.D. degree in the Department of Energy & Mineral Resources Engineering at Sejong University, where he investigated the effects of Fe doping element in NCM for LIBs, in 2019. While he was a postdoctoral fellow at Korea Electronics Technology Institute in Korea from 2019 to 2020, he worked on the development of cathode for all-solid-state batteries. After he worked as a research professor at Sejong University from 2020 to 2023, he is now working for Ascend Elements. His research areas include the development of novel and resynthesized cathode materials for LIBs and the recycling of spent LIBs. Dr. Park has published about 30 papers in peer-reviewed international SCI(E) journals. Kyungjung Kwon completed his Ph.D. in the Department of Materials Science & Engineering at UC Berkeley in the USA in 2001. After working as a postdoctoral fellow at National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science & Technology in Japan from 2002 to 2003, he worked for Samsung Electronics for the next seven years. In 2010, he joined as a faculty member in the Department of Energy & Mineral Resources Engineering at Sejong University. His research interests are focused on LIB cathode materials, LIB recycling, and catalysis in fuel cells. To date, Prof. Kwon has published about 100 papers in peer-reviewed international SCI(E) journals.

coredata.dc:description: This review highlights the importance of recovering valuable metals from spent Li-ion battery (LIB) cathodes through the resynthesis of cathode active materials (CAMs). The resynthesis process of CAMs, a promising recycling method that directly produces CAM precursors from LIB leachate, is explored. This process encompasses six key steps, including pretreatment, leaching, purification, adjustment of metal concentrations, precursor synthesis, and sintering. The review also investigates the potential introduction of impurity elements during CAM resynthesis and provides tolerance levels for these impurities based on thorough reference analysis. Additionally, it addresses challenges related to the commercialization of the resynthesis process. Notably, this review represents the first comprehensive assessment of CAM resynthesis, including the systematic evaluation of 12 impurity elements (Fe, Li, Al, Cu, C, P, F, Na, Cl, S, Mg, and Zn). Overall, this comprehensive review is poised to support the commercial development of resynthesized CAMs by offering valuable guidelines for managing impurities and streamlining the purification process.
